Maybe it was misinformation, but I recall, but when I first learned of this stuff, that the universe that 3 potential death scenarios.
1- The Big Crunch, the one that suggested the universe would eventually slow down and contract, and collide, potentially igniting a new Big Bang, in a sort of 'heartbeat' universe. (This one is now obsolete of course)
2- Big Freeze, expansion keeps on, but dark matter and normal matter manage to keep it relatively slow in it's acceleration, so the end result is the black void where everything is cold because all stars have moved too far away from each other.
3- Big Rip, universe expands, increasingly fast, and due to the exponential acceleration, at one point the speed would be such that structures would just.... vaporize as matter cannot hold on against the speed.

0:43 "All the galaxies we see are moving away from each other, as space expands between them; that is: on large scales! [...] on small scales the expansion is small, and on bigger scales the expansion is faster"
That's a flawed perspective, isn't it?
The expansion is not an actual movement of galaxies, but added distance ("new space" / space[- time] being stretched) in between. Thus the expansion never applies to two points in the universe, but to the universe as a whole [probably] equally; therefore it isn't appropriate to say, that "expansion is fast on this scale"; rather, that a light-particle that travels traveled through a certain gap, will have had more experienced expansion, than another particle that traveled a shorter distance. It's an important distinction to be made...

There's no such thing as "Dark Energy" or "Dark Matter". Our current theory of gravity is incomplete and uses problematic and outdated symmetry mathematics. One should instead apply Ussher's Equation, which uses so(2,3) = sp(2,R) symmetry. If you do this (and solve some extremely tedious but straightforward equations), then you'll find that gravity just behaves differently at really large distances,  in such a way that it stops "seeing" as much matter as actually exists. Bam, the absurd notions of Dark Matter and Dark Energy become unnecessary to explain the motion of galaxies and the expansion of the universe, and physics can stop with this ridiculous wild goose chase of finding things that aren't there.
